Fig 8 Research Paper Dual functional Z-scheme ReS2/CdIn2S4 catalyst efficiently photocatalyzes H2O2 production and CO2 reduction in pure water without sacrificial agents Wenhua Fu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Data curation Nan Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition ⁎ Qian Dong Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Gang Zhao Methodology Investigation Shirui Zhang Methodology Investigation Yi Wu Methodology Investigation Kai Zhao Methodology Investigation Jiangquan Ma Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Jiangsu Province Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu Province 213164, China Jiangsu Province Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu Province 213164 China Jiangsu Province Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu Province 213164, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Photocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction has been the hotspots in the field of chemical industry for a long time. CdIn2S4 is widely used due to its excellent thermal stability and significant absorption in the visible light region. However, the low efficiency of photogenerated charge separation hinders its practical application. In this work, Z-scheme heterojunction ReS2/CdIn2S4 was successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method and applied for the first time in photocatalytic production of H2O2 and CO2 reduction. The experimental results show that compared with pure CdIn2S4 or pure ReS2, the photocatalytic performance of ReS2/CdIn2S4 is greatly improved. When the loading amount of ReS2 is 12 wt. % of CdIn2S4, it exhibits the optimal photocatalytic H2O2 productivity of 361.8 μmol h-1 g-1 and the optimal yields of CO and CH4 of 89.84 and 5.03 μmol h-1 g-1 respectively in pure water. The Z-scheme heterojunction of ReS2/CdIn2S4 was determined by XPS and the band structure. In addition, two possible reaction pathways involving O2 - and 1O2 were analyzed for the H2O2 production by RS/CIS and the pathway of carbon dioxide reduction reaction can be speculated through in-situ DRIFTS. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photocatalytic Z-scheme heterojunction ReS2/CdIn2S4 H2O2 CO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), as an environmentally friendly and sustainable chemical, is widely used in wastewater treatment, sterilization and disinfection, and chemical synthesis [1]. H2O2 is usually produced through anthraquinone process in industry, but this process has problems such as high energy consumption and toxic by-products [2,3]. Solar energy is recognized as the most promising energy source due to its cleanliness and inexhaustibility, and photocatalysis technology enables emerging solar energy conversion [4–9]. The production of H2O2 via solar photocatalysis is regarded as a green method [10]. However, there are still issues with low H2O2 productivity and low carrier utilization. Many sacrificial reagents have been explored as hole scavengers to address the rapid separation and collection of photo generated electron hole pairs from semiconductors during H2O2 generation [11]. However, the addition of sacrificial agents not only increases costs, but also brings new challenges to revealing mechanisms. Therefore, the development of visible photosensitive photocatalysts for H2O2 synthesis without sacrificial agents is of great significance [12]. In addition, humans’ high dependence on fossil fuels leads to excessive levels of CO2 in the atmosphere, which is the major reason for the aggravation of the greenhouse effect [13,14]. Using photocatalysis to shift CO2 into ponderable chemicals and fuels effectively solves the greenhouse effect and energy shortage [15–18]. So far, people have been working on the shoots of various catalytic materials for H2O2 production or CO2 reduction. Among them, the ternary transition metal chalcogenide photocatalyst has aroused widespread concern owing to the appropriate band gap and position [19]. CdIn2S4 (CIS) is a typical ternary transition metal chalcogenide, which has excellent durability and noteworthy absorption in the region of visible light [20]. At present, CIS has been used for photocatalytic water splitting [21], photocatalytic degradation of pollutants [22], photocatalytic reduction of CO2 [23]. To solve this problem, there have been various attempts, including morphology control [24], element doping [25,26], loading cocatalysts [27], and construct heterojunctions [28,29]. In recent years, constructing compact Z-shaped and S-shaped heterostructures has become an effective strategy for achieving charge separation and photocatalytic performance [30]. A compact heterojunction interface can construct electronic channels and has a large internal electric field to enhance the transfer of charges to surface reaction sites [31,32]. Xie et al. found that compared with CdIn2S4 and ZnS, the CdIn2S4/ZnS Z-heterojunction can effectively suppress the recombination of photo generated electron hole pairs and improve the redox performance, which is beneficial for enhancing photocatalytic activity [33]. Because of their unique photoelectric properties, transition metal disulfides have aroused great concern [34]. Among them, two-dimensional (2D) layered rhenium disulfide (ReS2) with a direct bandgap of approximately 1.5 eV has attracted extensive attention, which is attributed to its dual functions as a traditional cocatalyst [35]. Meanwhile, it has been demonstrated as an efficient complementary photocatalyst that can broaden the visible-light absorption edge [36]. Liu et al. ReS2@Cu2O/Cu composite photocatalyst was prepared by drop casting method. The composite material has better CO2 photoreduction performance and electron-hole separation performance compared with pure Cu2O [37]. Suet al. ReS2 was successfully anchored on the surface of CdS/ZnS by simple hydrothermal method, which improved the photocatalytic performance and stability of CdS/ZnS [38]. Therefore, the addition of ReS2 may be helpful to realize photo-induced charge transfer and inhibit carrier recombination. According to our knowledge, there have been no reports that RS and CIS combine to form heterojunction for photocatalytic H2O2 production and CO2 reduction. Herein, the Z-scheme heterojunction ReS2/CdIn2S4 (RS/CIS) was synthesized successfully by hydrothermal method for photocatalytic production of H2O2 and CO2 reduction. The experimental results show that when the loading amount of ReS2 was 12 wt % of CIS, the optimal photocatalytic H2O2 precipitation rate in pure water and air was 361.8 μ mol h-1 g-1 and the optimum reduction rates of CO2 in pure water to CO and CH4 were 89.84. and 5.03 μmol h-1 g-1, respectively. Compared with pure CIS or pure ReS2, the photocatalytic performance was greatly improved. The heterojunction type of the prepared RS/CIS photocatalyst was explained by XPS and solid-state UV visible light. The reaction mechanism of the prepared RS/CIS photocatalyst for H2O2 production was elucidated through active radical capture experiments and electron paramagnetic tests. In situ DRIFTS spectra showed that *CH3O, *CHO and *COOH were the main key intermediates for photocatalytic reduction of CO2, and the mechanism of CO2 reduction can be inferred based. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials All the chemicals used in the experiment have not been further purified. Thiourea (NH4N2S, 99 %), Cadmium chloride hemi (pentahydrate) (CdCl2·2·5H2O, 98 %), Indium (III) chloride tetrahydrate (InCl3·4H2O, 98 %), Ammonium perrhenate (NH4ReO4, 99 %), and ethyl alcohol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. China. 2.2 Material synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of CIS Disperse 8 mmol Thiourea, 2 mmol Cadmium chloride hemi (pentahydrate), and 4 mmol Indium (III) chloride tetrahydrate into 60 mL deionized water and stirred for 1 h (Fig. 1 a). Then, the above mixture was put into an autoclave with PTFE lining and kept at 180 °C for 48 h. The washed orange precipitate was dried at 60 °C overnight and the product is collected Finally. 2.2.2 Preparation of RS 2 mmol Ammonium perrhenate and 9 mmol Thiourea were added to 60 mL of deionized water while stirring for 1 h (Fig. 1b). Then, the above mixture was put into an autoclave with a PTFE lining and kept at 240 °C for 24 h. The washed black precipitate was dried at 60 °C overnight and the product is collected Finally. 2.2.3 Preparation of RS/CIS 1000 mg CIS and (50, 120, 200 mg) RS are mixed by stirring for 22 h, then dry overnight at 60 °C. Finally, RS/CIS catalyst with different mass loading ratios (5 %, 12 % and 20 %) is obtained. 2.3 Photocatalytic performance testing experiment 2.3.1 Photocatalytic H2O2 production reaction Photocatalytic H2O2 production is implemented in the simulated sunlight irradiation. It is worth noting that the light source used is a 55 W Xe lamp. 0.05 g photocatalyst was added to 100 mL deionized water and sonicate for 2 min to disperse the catalyst. During the whole photocatalytic process, the photocatalytic reactor was maintained at 25 °C by cooling water circulation. After 1 hour of reaction, the supernatant was obtained by centrifugation. 1 mL of the supernatant was added to a mixed solution of 2 mL of 0.1 M potassium iodide (KI) and 2 mL of 0.01 M potassium hydrogen phthalate (C8H5KO4) and then oscillated in the microwave reactor for 15 min. Measure the absorbance of the mixed solution at 350 nm using UV visible spectroscopy to estimate the amount of H2O2 produced. The standard curve of the relationship between H2O2 concentration and absorbance is shown in Fig. S1. 2.3.2 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction 0.002 g of the photocatalyst was added to 20 mL of deionized water and ultrasonicated to obtain a homogeneous suspension. High-purity CO2 was then bubbled through the above-mentioned suspension for 30 min. After sealing, the reaction was carried out under irradiation of a 55 W Xenon Lamp for 2 h. Throughout the photocatalytic process, the photocatalytic reactor was maintained at 293 K using a cooling water circulation system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis of catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction was used to study the crystal structure of RS, CIS and RS/CIS composites. In the Fig. 2 , the main characteristic peaks of pure CIS are located at 47.4°, 43.3°, 33.0°, 27.2°, 23.2°, and 14.1°, which correspond to the (440), (511), (400), (311), (220), and (111) planes of CIS (JCPDS No. 27–0060) [39]. Pure RS has obvious diffraction peaks at 14.5° and 33.3°, corresponding to the (001) and (201) planes of RS (JCPDS No. 27–0502) [40]. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 2a, with the increase of RS content in the composite sample, the intensity of the diffraction peak located at 14.5° continuously increases, which confirms the successful composite of RS and CIS. In addition, these results strongly demonstrate the significant interactions between the components. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms in Fig. 2b shows a clear hysteresis loop in 12 % RS/CIS, confirming the loading of RS on CIS successfully. CIS and 12 % RS/CIS have specific surface areas of 1.56 and 13.11 m2 g-1. In addition, CIS and 12 % RS/CIS are part of mesoporous materials according to IUPAC standards. The specific surface area of RS is larger than that of CIS (Fig. 2c) when the loading of RS is 12 % of the mass of CIS, which may provide more adsorption and photocatalytic reaction sites, which is beneficial to photocatalytic performance [41]. The morphology and element distribution of CIS, RS and 12 % RS/CIS composites were characterized by SEM and EDS mappings. CIS has a dispersed spherical structure (Fig. 3 a), with a rough surface and a size distribution between 3–7 μm. The RS thin layer curls to form a flower-like structure and accumulates together (Fig. 3b), with a diameter of 1–2 μm. 12 % RS/CIS show flower-like microspheres with a diameter of about 8 μm (Fig. 3c). The EDS element mapping of 12 % RS/CIS composites (Fig. 3 g-k, S2) was carried out to describe the composition element distribution, and four elements Re, Cd, In and S are all observed. Furthermore, 12 % RS/CIS was tested by HRTEM (Fig. 3d-f) to prove the combination of CIS and RS. The 0.62 and 0.35 nm lattice spacing in Fig. 3f, corresponding to the (111) planes of CIS and the (102) planes of RS, respectively [42,43]. At the same time, it is easy to observe the obvious interface contact between RS and CIS in Fig. 3f. This is consistent with the XRD results. The elemental composition, phase structure and surface chemical state of photocatalysts were analyzed by XPS. Fig. S3 displayed the survey spectra of CIS, RS and 12 % RS/CIS. For 12 % RS/CIS, the electron orbitals of Re 4f5/2 and Re 4f7/2 corresponding to two peaks at 42.91 and 45.30 eV in XPS spectrum (Fig. 4 a), respectively [44]. Compared with Re in RS, the binding energy of Re in 12 % RS/CIS moves to a lower position, which may be caused by electron transfer in 12 % RS/CIS. The Cd 3d3/2 and Cd 3d5/2 of 12 % RS/CIS in high-resolution XPS spectrum can be divided into two peaks of 405.14 and 412.41 eV (Fig. 4b) [45]. The In 3d3/2 and In 3d5/2 orbitals are 452.43 and 444.86 eV (Fig. 4c), respectively [45]. The binding energy of Cd and in 12 % RS/CIS move to higher positions compared with CIS. As shown in Fig. 4d, the binding energies of S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 of RS are found at 163.83 and 162.50 eV [44], and the electronic orbitals of S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 of CIS are located at the two peaks of 162.72 and 161.48 eV, which can be attributed to the existence of S2- [46,47]. Obviously, the binding energies of S 2p1/2 (163.04 eV) and S 2p3/2 (161.74 eV) in 12 % RS/CIS are positively shifted compared to the binding energy in CIS, and negatively shifted compared to the binding energy in RS. Therefore, it can be inferred that electrons transfer from CIS to RS, and there is a strong interaction between RS and CIS, which can prove the formation of heterojunction at the RS/CIS interface [45]. RS/CIS may follow two electron hole transport pathways: type II and type Z heterojunctions. If the carrier migration of RS/CIS follows the type II heterojunction mechanism, photo generated electrons will migrate from RS CB to CIS CB, and holes in CIS VB will migrate to RS VB, which is inconsistent with the direction of electron flow from CIS to RS as determined by XPS analysis. Therefore, the charge transfer path between RS/CIS does not follow the Type II mechanism, but follows the Type Z mechanism. 3.2 Photocatalytic H2O2 production and CO2 reduction performance The photocatalytic H2O2 generation process of the prepared catalyst was studied under simulated sunlight irradiation. The yield of H2O2 is shown in Fig. 5 a, and the production rate of H2O2 in the RS/CIS heterojunction is higher than that of pure CIS and pure RS. It is worth noting that 12 % RS/CIS exhibited the highest H2O2 yield of 361.8 μmol h-1 g-1, which is 2.54 times that of pure CIS (142.5 μmol h-1 g-1) and 8.78 times that of pure RS (41.2 μmol h-1 g-1), respectively. As shown in Fig. 5b, the H2O2 reduction performance of the RS/CIS photocatalyst remains above 85 % after five cycles, which indicates that the prepared ReS2/CdIn2S4 material has excellent photocatalytic stability. Further, the samples of RS/CIS which have been subjected to photocatalytic reaction after 5 cycles were characterized by XRD (Fig. S4) and HRTEM (Fig. S5). The results show that the crystal structure and shape of the sample have hardly changed, which reflects that RS/CIS material has satisfied durability. The precipitation rate of H2O2 in the synthesized RS/CIS solid solution is higher than that of pure CIS. The photocatalytic reduction of CO2 by CIS, 5 % RS/CIS, 12 % RS/CIS and 20 % RS/CIS under simulated sunlight irradiation was studied (Fig. 6 c, d). The CO and CH4 evolution rates of 12 % RS/CIS are 89.84 and 5.03 μmol h-1 g-1, which are higher than those of pure CIS (35.41 and 1.21 μmol h-1 g-1). 3.3 Optical property of material The energy band structure of CIS and RS was explored to further understand the charge transfer route. In Fig. 6a, the solid UV–vis absorption spectra of CIS, RS and 12 % RS/CIS are tested. CIS collects light from ultraviolet to visible light, and its absorption edge is about 590 nm. RS can be absorbed the complete UV to visible light region from 200 to 800 nm. Additionally, it is worth noting that compared to CIS, the visible light absorption range of composite materials has significantly increased, which can be extended to the entire ultraviolet to visible light range. Furthermore, the band gap energy can be estimated by the following formula: αhν = A(hν−Eg)1/n [48], where ν, h, α and A denote frequencies, Planck constants, absorption coefficients and constants, respectively. n is a constant related to the transmission properties of semiconductors. Among them, the type of semiconductor optical transition can determine the value of n. When the catalyst is a direct band gap semiconductor, n is taken as 2, and when the catalyst is an indirect band gap, n is taken as 1/2 [49]. Since CIS and RS are direct band gap semiconductor materials, the values of n is taken as 2. In Fig. 6b, the band gaps are calculated to be 2.29 and 1.59 eV for CIS and RS, respectively. the results are consistent with previous reports [47,50]. The valence band (VB) positions determined by VB-XPS spectra are 1.49 and 0.47 eV for CIS and RS (Fig. 6c). As shown in Fig. 6d, the VB values of CIS and RS are more negative than the standard oxidation–reduction potential of H2O/•OH (2.73 eV) [51,52]. In theory, the h + generated by CIS or RS cannot oxidize H2O to produce •OH radicals. Compared with the standard oxidation–reduction potential of H2O/O2 (1.23 eV) [6,52], the position of the CIS valence band is more positive, indicating that the decomposition of H2O into O2 is a possible reaction pathway. In addition, the standard redox potential •O2 -/1O2 (0.33 eV) is not higher than the VB values of CIS and RS indicating that the •O2 - can be converted into 1O2. Based on the Eg values calculated by UV–vis absorption spectra and VB-XPS spectrum, it can be estimated that the CB values of CIS and RS are −0.8 and −1.12 eV, respectively. the CB values of CIS and RS are more negative than the standard redox potential O2/•O2 - (−0.33 eV) [52], which is inferred that the production of H2O2 may be due to the O2 reduction pathway. The CB of CIS and RS is more negative than the standard redox potential of CO2/CO (−0.53 eV) and CO2/CH4 (−0.24 eV), reducing CO2 can also occur in theory and produce CO and CH4. As shown in Fig. 6c, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) reveals that the arc radius of 12 % RS/CIS is smaller compared with those of CIS and RS, indicating lower charge transfer resistance for 12 % RS/CIS. This is beneficial for improving its photocatalytic performance [53]. As illustrated in Fig. 6f, the photoluminescence (PL) intensity of 12 % RS/CIS is significantly lower than those of CIS and RS, which can be attributed to the effective promotion of carrier separation in 12 % RS/CIS. This finding is consistent with the results of EIS. 3.4 Mechanism of photocatalytic H2O2 production and CO2 reduction As shown in Fig. 7 a, in order to investigate the mechanism of reaction, free radical scavenging experiments were conducted. Nitrobenzene, disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetate (EDTA-2Na), p-benzoquinone (BQ), l-tryptophan, and isopropanol (IPA) were used as scavengers for e-, h +, ·O2 -, 1O2, and ·OH, respectively. Under simulated sunlight, the addition of BQ resulted in almost zero yield of H2O2, indicating that O2 - is a critical intermediate in the photocatalytic production of H2O2. After adding l-tryptophan as a scavenger for singlet oxygen (1O2), the production of H2O2 decreased by 60 % compared to the blank group, indicating the important role of 1O2 in the photocatalytic production of H2O2. When the scavengers of e- and h + are added, the significant decrease in H2O2 yield indicates that e- and h + play equally important roles in the reaction process. The addition of IPA has a negligible impact on the reaction process, indicating that ·OH has almost no effect on the reaction process. In order to further verify the important role of various free radicals in photocatalytic H2O2 production, different trapping agents were selected for electron paramagnetic testing of the material. 5,5´-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) is used as the spin-trapping agents for ∙O2 - and ·OH, 2,2,6,6-Tetra-methy1–1-piperidinyloxy (TEMPO) is used as the spin-trapping agents for h + and e-, and 4-Amino-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine (TEMP) is used as the spin-trapping agents for 1O2. In Fig. 7b and c, signals of ·O2 - and 1O2 can be observed after illumination, indicating the presence of ·O2 - and 1O2 during the photocatalytic production of H2O2. This is consistent with the results of free radical scavenging experiments and is consistent with the bandgap position of the material. (As shown in Fig. S6, the blank test tube also shows a peak around 337.1, indicating that the peak around 337.1 may attributed to the instrument peak.) In addition, the peaks of e- and h + can also be clearly observed in Fig. S7. As is well known, ·O2 - can be converted to 1O2 in the presence of h + (·O2 - + h + → 1O2) [54,55]. To further verify the formation process of 1O2, the ESR signal of 1O2 was detected after capturing ·O2 - using BQ. As shown in the Fig. 7d, the signal observed in the 12 % RS/CIS + BQ + TEM system is in the same position as the signal observed in the BQ+TEM system. That is to say, apart from the signal appearance of the interaction between BQ and TEMP, no signal peak of 1O2 can be observed, indicating that 1O2 is converted from ·O2 -. In addition, only the characteristic signal of DMPO was observed in DMPO-·OH, and no signal of ·OH was observed, indicating that H2O2 cannot be generated through the (·OH → H2O2) process. This is consistent with the captured experimental results and conforms to the material bandgap rules. Based on the characterization of active free radical scavenging experiments, solid UV–vis and XPS, the possible mechanism of Z-scheme RS/CIS heterojunction was shown in Fig. 7f. When light (HV>Eg) is irradiated onto RS and CIS, the electron absorption energy on VB is transferred to their respective CBs, forming electron hole pairs. The electrons on CIS CB are transferred to RS VB. The composition of RS and CIS exhibits a constructive band arrangement, which is necessary for effective separation and channeling of photogenerated carriers. Firstly, H2O decomposes into O2 and H + under the action of h +, and O2 is reduced to form •O2 -. A portion of •O2 - is reduced to H2O2 by photo generated electrons, while another portion of •O2 - combines with h + to form 1O2, which then reacts with H + and e- to form H2O2. In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) was used to study the key intermediate products produced in the experiment, so as to explore the process of photocatalytic reduction of CO2. The obtained RS/CIS composite catalyst was dried at 120 °C for 150 min to ensure the removal of all organic solvents. The specific results are shown in Fig. 8 a. Firstly, carbon dioxide was introduced into the dark environment moistened with water vapor, and the RS/CIS composite catalyst was adsorbed inside for 30 min, and the group was measured every 10 min. Then the light was added and maintained for 60 min, during which the group was detected every 10 min. Samples are exposed to the mixture of CO2 and water, resulting in the formation of primary carbonate species on its surface, namely carboxylates (COO-, 1242 cm-1) [56]. It can be seen that COO- has been formed under dark conditions, and the content of this group has increased after illumination. In addition, the contents of bicarbonate (HCO3 -, 1436, 1206 and 1201 cm-1) [56,57], methoxy (*CH3O, 1030 and 1156 cm-1) [58], monodentate carbonate (m-CO3 2-, 1510–1560 cm-1) [59], bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2-, 1583 and 1345 cm-1)[59] increased significantly after light irradiation. It is worth noting that the peaks at 1270 and 1338 cm-1 belong to *COOH, which is an important key intermediate for the formation of CO. And the peaks in the range of 1660–1716 cm-1 are caused by C = O stretching vibration and O C = O asymmetric stretching, corresponding to *CHO and *COOH [60]. Due to the conversion between m-C3 2-/b-CO3 2-/HCO3 -/*CHO/*CH3O and the consumption of *COOH, these peak intensities remain in balance during the reaction [61,62]. The In-situ DRIFTS results show that the Z-scheme heterojunction RS/CIS composite catalyst has a certain reduction ability to CO2 in the dark, and the reduction ability of the material to CO2 is further enhanced after the addition of light. The conversion of CO2 undergoes a multi-step reaction involving a series of intermediates such as *COOH, *CH3O and *CHO, and finally converted into CO and CH4. Due to the non-polarity of the molecular structure and its low affinity with the surface of the photocatalyst, CH4 molecules cannot be detected in the spectrum [57]. The possible pathways for CO2 reduction to CO and CH4 are shown in Fig. 8b 4 Conclusion In summary, we constructed RS/CIS composites by simple hydrothermal and impregnation method. The results showed that the optimized RS/CIS photocatalyst had H2O2 yield of 361.8 μmol h-1 g-1 in pure water and air. In addition, the yields of CO and CH4 in pure water were 89.84 and 5.03 μmol h-1 g-1, respectively. Through a series of characterizations, it is proved that the Z-scheme heterojunction is formed between ReS2 and CdIn2S4, which can effectively enhance utilization of light and separation rate of photogenerated electrons and holes. The mechanism of H2O2 production was explored by capture experiments and free radical scavenging experiments. It is proven that •O2 - and 1O2 played an important role in the process of photocatalytic pure water splitting to produce H2O2. Moreover, the conversion of CO2 undergoes a multi-step reaction involving a series of intermediates by in situ DRIFTS. This work offers novel insights into RS/CIS achieving outstanding performance in photocatalytic H2O2 production and CO2 photoreduction. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction has been the hotspots in the field of chemical industry for a long time. CdIn2S4 is widely used due to its excellent thermal stability and significant absorption in the visible light region. However, the low efficiency of photogenerated charge separation hinders its practical application. In this work, Z-scheme heterojunction ReS2/CdIn2S4 was successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method and applied for the first time in photocatalytic production of H2O2 and CO2 reduction. The experimental results show that compared with pure CdIn2S4 or pure ReS2, the photocatalytic performance of ReS2/CdIn2S4 is greatly improved. When the loading amount of ReS2 is 12 wt. % of CdIn2S4, it exhibits the optimal photocatalytic H2O2 productivity of 361.8 μmol h-1 g-1 and the optimal yields of CO and CH4 of 89.84 and 5.03 μmol h-1 g-1 respectively in pure water. The Z-scheme heterojunction of ReS2/CdIn2S4 was determined by XPS and the band structure. In addition, two possible reaction pathways involving O2 - and 1O2 were analyzed for the H2O2 production by RS/CIS and the pathway of carbon dioxide reduction reaction can be speculated through in-situ DRIFTS.
coredata.dc:title: Dual functional Z-scheme ReS2/CdIn2S4 catalyst efficiently photocatalyzes H2O2 production and CO2 reduction in pure water without sacrificial agents
